etymologies: mid 17th century: from Narragansett squaws ‘woman’, with related forms in many Algonquian dialects

notes.text: Until relatively recently, the word squaw was used neutrally in anthropological and other contexts to mean a North American Indian woman or wife. With changes in the political climate in the second half of the 20th century, however, the derogatory attitudes of the past toward North American Indian women mean that the word cannot now be used in any sense without being regarded as offensive

definitions: a North American Indian woman or wife.
shortDefinitions: North American Indian woman or wife
